meta_data.title: Mark Legg // Part 2 — A Faith To Cling To

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner, joined as always by my partners in crime, Bryn Starnes and Chris Legg. And we have Mark Legge again here for this episode to continue kind of this conversation about kind of personal stories of walking through life, interacting with difficult situations or difficult questions and still being anchored to faith in Jesus. And so Mark, thanks for being on. I really appreciate it. Chris, can I throw it over to you? Yeah. Because you had a thought for this portion of our discussion with Mark talking about kind of anchoring. Well, so here's a, I think for many of us, when we face challenges to our beliefs or we face some new idea, one of the things we forget is that every viewpoint has difficult things that has to answer. And so when you go, okay, this is challenging my faith as it is, but if I took the other stance, I would then have to come up with an answer still for several problems. I mean, the other viewpoint has its issues as well. And as we talked about in the last episode with Mark, every human is going to be wrong at times. That's a given, right? All humans. At least at the just base level, no one makes a 100 on every math paper they ever turn. That's just not human. Humans don't do that. In fact, we've talked about before that I think Jesus' experience on earth was that he was sinless but not flawless. I think he probably missed questions on his math tests and even on his Hebrew tests. And that may panic some people, but I don't think it should. I think he took sometimes more than one hit of the hammer for him to put a nail in a board. He wasn't flawless. He was sinless. Or tripped and fell. Or tripped and fell, exactly. Or got something on his face and didn't know it. I feel like all the things we face as humans, right? So anyway, I think that's an interesting conversation as we're having. But I think for us, there's a couple for me that I fall back on. What happened with the disciples then? If Jesus was not born, lived, died, and was raised from the grave, I'm going to have to come up with an alternative theory for what happened to a bunch of Hebrew men and women 2,000 years ago that is historically accepted. I mean, there are fringe people who don't accept it, but historically you're stuck with the fact that Christianity came from something. And that this is the probably... Well, I'm going to have to come up with an alternative answer for that. And I can't... So far, I've never come up with one. So that's something I fall back on when I go, oh, but what about the problem of suffering? What do I do with that? Because I think that's one of the tough... Often a tough question. I go, okay, but if I switch some views on this, I'm going to need to come up with a solution for this problem. Or for me, the teleological argument, which we've talked about, is the most potent. The idea that there's such an obvious cause and effect relationship between, especially with designed things that I feel like I would be having to have a psychotic break to pretend like, no, no, just random chance led to random chance processes. Very complex random chance processes led to this. And I just don't know that I could make my brain go there. I don't know that I have to quote faith to do that. there's right and wrong. Okay, so then we can just work from backwards. Okay, this is clearly wrong.
And then work backwards from what's obviously wrong. You know, racism is obviously wrong. Let's
define that. What is that? That's wrong. So what's right? And then you just move in that direction,
you say, okay, well, then you do believe in right and wrong. You do make judgments. So that's just
what I would, I would argue is you can be a seeker of truth while still being reminded.
That's great. That's, that's really good. I think that's, and I think that's something that will be
encouraging for our listeners who are in that place. Yeah, I think your, I think your story,
and I think the insights in this episode have been really helpful. And I think it's a great place for
people. I agree. It also, I think also delineating like what is, you know, what is true open-mindedness?
It kind of lends itself to what, you know, Chris, what you've told us several times of like,
I've tried to get into these open-minded discussion boards. Yeah, yeah. And no one wants me.
We want our own version of free thinking. No one else. So it's like, oh, I think that's also
just a good reiteration of let's understand what that is. And we don't have to check our minds
at the door. Yeah. And I think being free thinking and open-minded is a concept that everyone loves.
And it's something that we want to claim about ourselves, but the work of actually knowing what
that means in a healthy way and actually doing the work to be that way is like sometimes painful and
really difficult. And so it's sometimes it's more like, we just want to feel like we're open-minded,
you know, or feel like we've arrived at the answers or whatever version of that is.
And it's a fun thing to claim, but then it's like, have we actually put in the work to know,
like you're saying, know what that actually means and then to actually be.
Yeah, yeah. That is so true. That is one of the most prominent, I claim it for myself
and yet isn't actually true out there. Right. Yeah. Like, oh man, that's such a good insight.
Like that is one of the top things, like claiming humility for yourself. Everyone would claim to
be humble. Everyone would claim to be open-minded. Nowadays, everyone would claim to be open-minded,
but are they really? And the answer is that that's such a great point. Typically no. Yeah.
Because humans, humans just aren't, we're not very open-minded. We have moments maybe of open-mindedness,
but that's about as far as we get. Yeah. Wonderful. Well, Mark, Mark, thank you for,
for being on, for sharing your thoughts, for sharing your story. And I'm confident that this
will meet our listeners wherever they are on their journey. And I'm sure it will help one,
spur them on to be thinking maybe in a different way, but also just to be encouraged by your faith
through hard questions of life. I appreciate it. Yep. Thank you, Mark. Thank you, Mark.
Appreciate your son. This is so great. Thank you guys so much. Alrighty.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info
at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
